Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CC-NIE Integration: Developing Applications with Networking Capabilities via End-to-End SDN (DANCES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The DANCES project team of network engineers, application developers, and research scientists is implementing a software-defined networking (SDN)-enabled end-to-end environment to optimize support for scientific data transfer. DANCES accomplishes this optimization by integrating high performance computing job scheduling, network control capabilities offered by SDN along with data movement applications in an end-to-end network infrastructure. This integration provides access to control mechanisms for managing network bandwidth. The control of network resources enabled by SDN enhances application stability, predictability and performance, thereby improving overall network utilization. Motivation for the DANCES project is to apply the advantages of advanced network services to the problem of congested metropolitan and campus networks. DANCES uses XSEDENet across Internet2 in conjunction with OpenFlow-enabled network switches installed at the collaborating sites as the end-to-end hardware and software substrate.

Knowledge gained through DANCES is being disseminated through educational programs offered by the participating institutions and at existing community workshops, meetings, and conferences. The insights and experience obtained through DANCES will promote a better understanding of the technical requirements for supporting end-to-end SDN across wide area and campus cyberinfrastructure. The resulting SDN-enabled applications will make the request and configuration of high bandwidth connections easily accessible to end users and improve network performance and predictability for supporting a wide range of applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The motivation for our project, Collaborative Research: CC-NIE Integration: Developing Applications with Networking Capabilities via End-to-End SDN (DANCES), was to address the problem of inefficient data movement across congested metropolitan and end site campus networks.  While many research and education sites have access to wide area connections across uncongested, very high speed (100Gbits/sec) backbone network links, connectivity within a site and at the site's edge is often limited to a maximum of 10Gbits/sec. These local networks are often congested with many types of network traffic competing for bandwidth. The result is that movement of very large data sets between bandwidth-limited sites takes hours or days to complete. With the competition for bandwidth, the many small, routine data transfers may either disrupt a large transfer, or be blocked, depending on network infrastructure design. This unmanaged use of network resources can result in sub-optimal utilization of not only the network, but also of storage and compute resources that are left idle while waiting for data to be delivered.

To address this inefficiency of bandwidth usage, researchers at Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC), University of Tennessee's National Institute for Computational Sciences (UT-NICS), and Pennsylvania State University (Penn State) proposed the DANCES project to develop and integrate mechanisms to manage network bandwidth in support of some commonly used file transfer applications. The targeted transfer applications included job resource scheduling when initiating GridFTP and GSISCP and the wide-area distributed file system SLASH2, developed by PSC. The project team identified the flexible programmability offered by software-defined networking (SDN) technology as a promising method for creating a data movement application-to-network control interface.

The DANCES team evaluated, selected, and deployed hardware and software to create a testbed comprising SDN-capable components at each site and connected over the wide area network. With the testbed in place, we developed an SDN controller, a bandwidth request processor and manager, and the bandwidth request scripts and interfaces to be used with the resource management and wide area file system software. Through a series of functionality and throughput testing, we verified successful operation of bandwidth request, allocation, and data transfer at the specified rate, thereby demonstrating that SDN was an appropriate technology to meet the project goals.

The DANCES project began at an early stage in the deployment of SDN for general use across the wide area network and spanning administrative domains. Results of the project have contributed to the developing body of SDN knowledge in the community. These results include: outcomes from hardware switch and SDN controller evaluations for wide-area applicability; recommendations for controller functions that are necessary but not always included with basic open source frameworks; architectural guidance for managing cross-domain installations; and experience from testing and verifying operation of the bandwidth control mechanisms. Through system development, deployment, and testing, the project provided the DANCES researchers with a valuable opportunity to gain expertise in leading-edge SDN technology. The DANCES project implementation demonstrated how advanced networking capabilities could be integrated and used to enhance the operation of a research network environment.
